the vibrant ecosystem of projects and tooling that have emerged to sort of tie
the jam stack together so why the damn stack and this will be
brief because I know in many of the talks today we've heard about the
benefits of the damn stack but humor me for a minute more performant if it's
pre-built you avoid spending the time rendering on the server and pre-built
files served over CDN or delivered superfast it's more secure with just
static files you minimize your attack vector it's less expensive hosting of
static files is cheap or even free and you have less overhead with not needing
to maintain your own servers better dev experience you can focus on the front
end without being walked into this monolithic architecture and easily
scalable so serving static files you don't have to worry about scaling up
servers in response to increased load so that all sounds super legit and really
read but like ok where do you go from there we heard Matt talk earlier about
this shift from to the front end as the king or queen from the monolith as the
king or queen but the freedom of breaking out of a monolithic CMS comes
with a really overwhelming number of choices and decisions that you have to

react years ago it's the tooling and the environment set up all around it was
really demanding even just compared to learning even more so than the learning
react so this brave new world of development comes with this whole new

this to me would be like me telling you make a cake not giving you any

you what kind of cake to make just saying do it well I know there's flour

- this the vibrant jam stack ecosystem and sort of how how to evaluate it and

it's been really cool to watch the space develop especially over the last couple
years and all these different frameworks and tool sets by necessity have

citrix team talking about their jekyll project Jekyll was my first static site
generator myself hugo uses go and they fall on the scale between fully static -
as Tanner talked about something more like static progressive they prioritize
different things for optimizing for performance some have a ton of structure
some have more flexibility and less structure but they're all different
recipes all different takes on the jam stack so now we're accidentally sorted
back to the problem of having an overwhelming sort of daunting number of
choices so I'll ask you a different cake questions what characteristics do you
value in a cake it has to have the flavors you want it has to have the
texture you want maybe you're super focused on the decoration and the
presentation but it still has to taste good or you don't really care about how
it looks you just want it to taste good it's your cake your choice so instead
what characteristics do you value in a website or a web it's got to be fast
time is money for users it's got to be performant you
don't want to be unnecessarily costing users tons of data you don't want to be
excluding people it has to be accessible it has to have well conceived content
has to be easily maintainable maybe it needs to be in a certain stack most of
your team is already comfortable comfortable with so you don't have a big
ramp up time so all of these questions and how they're prioritized depend on
your project needs your priorities your business requirements etc the reality is
we only have so much time personal time for personal projects
and budgeted time for paid projects so all of these wants and requirements are
really sort of dials that we have to balance to stay within whatever our
budget is some core concerns that I think are important when evaluating
frameworks that different varying strengths and weaknesses are how they
approach performance what methods they use toward performance how they approach
accessibility how they manage content and data what the developer experience
looks like and the community around the project so identifying your own core
concerns and how they align and your priorities set is sort of step one and
evaluating what tool might be your best option
and I'll reiterate again frameworks by necessity have varying levels of
structure and opinion and flexibility depending on your needs you need to have
enough flexibility not to be constrained but you also need to have enough
structure that you can get going productively and not sort of be have
this indecision paralysis so in talking through this set of core concerns I'm
going to talk about Gatsby specifically as an example but I think this is a
useful thought process to go through when comparing all of the available
tools so performance optimizing for performance involves considering payload
optimization like reducing image and JavaScript load differing below the fold
image calls and lining critical CSS and delivery optimizations like serving
static files from a CDN the good news is these approaches are complementary but
the bad news is in order to do it well you often have to do both which takes a
lot of time and specialization and focus so again different frameworks are based
on different approaches to performance and different levels of focus and
prioritizing performance to talk through a few key pieces to how Gatsby
approaches performance first route based code splitting we
create smaller bundles for specific routes and shared bundles for common
code it allows us to fulfill only what the user needs at the time they need it
and Gatsby takes care of this under the hood by default use HTTP 2 to serve
assets aside from being a mouthful HTTP 2 is a major revision of the HTTP
network protocol it leaves the semantics of HTTP intact that modifies how the
data is formatted and transported between the server and the client to
make the request response cycle more efficient in HTTP 1 the cycle looks
something like this here the first request is for an HTML file the server
responds with the file the browser parses it and as it discovers other
references to things like style sheets and scripts and images it will
separately fire off those requests using HTTP 2 instead multiple HTTP requests
can be sent and received via a single connection so again here we have our
initial index study HTML request that gets returned and again as the browser
goes through and parses and discovers these different references it can
request and receive responses but this time on the same connection so it's a
little bit more efficient and then further HTTP to enable server push which
will let us send site assets to the browser before it even knows it needs
them so in this scenario again firing off a request for index.html but this
time our server is intelligent enough to know that it should just go ahead and
push and fire off these different assets that we've already told it we're going
to need so cutting down on that cycle time if you're using mattified to manage
deploying it gatsby site you can use the GAT speeds Matloff I plug-in so you take
advantage of HTTP 2 and server push critical gatsby scripts by default so 3
set up background prefetching prefetching use
browser idle time to prefetch resources a user will definitely definitely or
likely need in the near future there are different ways to do this
there's predictive prefetching which Janet mentioned this morning which uses
analytics to enable prefetching based on a user's likely behavior based on the
way users have interacted with your site in the past and another is to observe
the user's interaction with the page and react accordingly which is sort of how
it works in Gatsby Gatsby has a link component for internal routing that
enables prefetching and for that link component there are sort of two pieces
to how that works first we is the intersection observer
API which is a browser API that sees to perform some action when an element
enters or leaves the viewport this is an example visualizing the intersection
observer API you can see as I'm scrolling up and down the page as
elements enter and leave the viewport the emoji change what based on whether
they're coming into view or in view or leaving the view or hidden so and gatsby
onload if a link is in the viewport or above-the-fold prefetching will be
triggered for that route if a link enters the viewport on scroll resources
for that route will be triggered for pre-chat prefetch as well
these prefetch requests are heavily deprioritized
and will only fire when the browser's idle we sort of politely hint to the
browser that these are resources that will likely be needed in the near future
but when a user actually actively hovers over links which strongly indicates that
they'll navigate to that route will actually fetch resources at a higher
priority so here circles back I'm on the gatsby home page and as I hover over the
nav items you can see these reflects these requests reflected in the network
tab in this cascade of requests so by the time I'm actually clicking on the in
this case the tutorial page the resources that we need for that
are already loaded and it feels super snappy for lazy load non-critical assets
lazy lighting is a technique that puts offloading of non-critical resources at
page load time instead letting them only when they're needed a great example of
this in Gatsby is the Gatsby image component which is designed to work with
the Gatsby data layer to optimize images and image loading on Gatsby sites this
is a screenshot of the demo site for Gatsby image and as you scroll an
intersection observer fires and you actually load needed images in place
which you can see again in this cascade of requests in the network tab it also
optimizes images by default at Build time because optimizing image is
low-hanging fruit for performance and should be easy in default so with Gatsby
image you not only get image optimization by default you're not even
serving optimized images if they're not needed by the user 5 use the
serviceworker a serviceworker is a web worker that runs in the browser
separately from the main thread it essentially allows your site to act as
its own network proxy for requests so for example if you're living a route
that requires an image the serviceworker can sort of act as the middleman and say
well do i already have this image cached and if it does have it cached it can go
ahead and return it to you and forgo making that redundant request if it
doesn't have it it can go ahead and send for it get it back cache it return it to
you that way if and when you need the image again at that point it's not
making a redundant request so doing this can speed up the loading and rendering
of pages considerably and gatsby for adding a serviceworker
again we turn to the plugin ecosystem the offline plugin adds drop-in support
for making a Gatsby site work offline and more resistant to low-quality
network connections it creates a serviceworker and loads it in the client
for you this plug-in works best with the Manifest plugin which when used together
get you most of the way toward fulfilling the baseline requirements for
a progressive web app all of this might be adding up to sound a little bit
familiar if you're familiar with the purple pattern which Gatsby follows this
is a pattern that was coined by the Google polymer team and is essentially a
methodology for building web apps that load quickly and reliably you push the
resources you need to get interactive and render the initial route quickly and
then use a serviceworker for caching and pre-caching resources and then lazy load
brats that you need on demand 6 only ship live code if the user doesn't need
it don't make them download it with tree
shaking you identify identify code that's not being used so that you can
eliminate it and gatsby Wiis web pack and terse urge asks for this and the
build process web pack will mark the unused code and tercer will eliminate it
during the minification process 7 serve static files
we're here at jams conf obviously so we've heard today about the benefits of
serving static assets so I'm going to talk a little bit about how Gatsby
leverages static assets when people think static assets it might be
reasonable to think wow I can't have a static site because I want my site to be
dynamic but static assets don't mean a static gap gatsby server-side vendors at
build time producing static HTML when a user hits a Gatsby site they're
initially served that pre-rendered static HTML
after that initial static load the site is rehydrated into a react app much like
what you heard from Tanner this one so you get fast subsequent page loads
and all the benefits of single page apps on top of a really fast initial static
render so I've talked about some of the main approaches gatsby takes to baking
in performance and it's basically in service of this idea that we don't have
to re-engineer setup or optimizations for a highly performant baseline we
don't have to fully reinvent our own recipes from scratch every time and
again I'm using Gatsby as an example and the tech that Gatsby is built on but if
you have love for view j/s or some other stack there's something out there like
next and be press so whatever it is there's a running start out there in the
ecosystem that aligns with your needs for flexibility and structure the next
core concern accessibility the same way we just talked about baking and
performance for a head start we can consider how we can do the same for
accessibility and again baked in what you can when you navigate on a
traditional Easter be rendered site the previous page is fully torn down and the
new page is reloaded and in response to this a screen reader can announce the
new content in a predictable way single page apps on the other hand rerender in
the client which makes for a faster more seamless visual experience but can
produce a broken experience for screen reader users so without the page reload
if we haven't properly managed focus in a manual way they won't know that new
content has been loaded to focus or to announce to the user and Gatsby's
version two we switched to using reach router which prioritizes accessibility
as a first-class concern and it provides out-of-the-box focus management for
client-side apps so gonna repeat myself a tiny bit here but when you visit a
Gatsby site a static server rendered HTML page is loaded first and then the
JavaScript to hydrate the site into a web app is loaded
from there again internal routing is handled with the Gatsby link component
but that link component actually wraps reach routers link component so using
reach router we can bake some of these concerns more straight in also leverage
linting tools just like you probably use linting to guard against human error and
enforce consistent code style and code bases when you're working with a team
team or even by yourself you can use linting to avoid some common
accessibility pitfalls at least the ones that are programmatically identifiable
so gatsby core uses the es link configuration that is used and put out
by a create react app which is Facebook's tool to get started with
creating a react up that configuration uses rules from the
JSX a 11y plugin for es lint which checks accessibility rules on JSX
elements so during development the linter will give you accessibility
warnings to address and resolve as you go again because accessibility isn't a
feature you don't add it at the end you can lean on your tools like linters and
editors and stuff to give you hints and addresses issues as you go so I'm a
Gatsby team we're constantly looking for ways to improve education and raise
awareness through our Doc's are available learning materials for people
to build accessible experiences for the web and as a team we're also continuing
to evolve our approach to accessibility both in the core tooling and what we put
into the wider Gatsby ecosystem so the team has been working on drafting
Gatsby's accessibility statement which is led by Marcy Sutton
so the initial draft this right here was merged on Monday yesterday which I'm
really excited about so y'all should all check it out so as the statement says we
want everyone who uses Gatsby to feel welcome and find the experience
rewarding this includes developers with disabilities and users with disabilities
for Gatsby's likes doctors and resources next we're concerned managing content
and data again we talked about this earlier monolithic CMS's are being
replaced by these modular specialized content systems and nowadays your data
can come from anywhere you can't tell just by looking at a site
but earlier we talked about about the a in gem stack this proliferation of
specialized purpose-built tools exposed to an AP is we do things like
Poland's search for mouth algo Lea because algo Lea prioritizes and is
really good at search or pulling assets from cloud marry because cloud iner is
really good at managing assets or pulling content from contempo or sanity
or any of the other headless CMS's because they're
purpose-built to manage content we pull and stuff to manage our commerce from
stripe or Shopify because that's they were designed to be good at so again we
don't have to reinvent or re-engineer a lot of these things but we should be
able to use them all together in ways that are sane and manageable the term
we're using to describe this shift is the content mesh which is the
infrastructure layer for a decoupled web site the decoupled monolith the content
mesh stitches together content systems in a modern dev environment so again
this allows you to select purpose-built tailored solutions for distinct use
cases and provides a modern framework for rapid iteration and empowers
developers while preserving content creators flows so in this scenario gasps
Gatsby is the glue for the content mesh guess we can consume data pretty much
from anywhere and when you source data into Gatsby it gets normalized into the
Gatsby data layer using graph QL we use graph QL because we think it's uniquely
well-suited to serve as this integration layer between the data and your
presentation layer so after all this is said and done all of your data is
consolidated into this uniformly queryable layer or not you can also
handle data outside of Gatsby's data layer and just use it directly which may
sometimes be a good option for prototyping or getting your feet wet
with gatsby or if you just don't want to use graph QL next core concern developer
experience when you're developing you want to get
productive fast whatever that means to you to me that means a tool that enables
me to use a modern stack without having to reinvent the wheel it should tanea
should absorb the overhead of setting up an environment from scratch and take
that off my plate with Gatsby that looks like react
webpack graph QL ESX support etc along with that should provide optimized
builds out-of-the-box with Gatsby you don't have to tune your own web pack
config setup code splitting manually optimize images instead you start with
an optimized baseline with the opportunity to customize or break out of
those defaults by choice selectively where you need to you should also be
able to leverage the collective work of the community with nodejs and NPM and
yarn the JavaScript world has a really rich shared ecosystem and on top of that
and gatsby there's this amazing community of plugins and starters and
more recently experimentally Gatsby themes so Brandon some of the stuff well
I thought a great developer experience it's one that you never have to think
about it just gets totally out of the way and let you focus lets you focus on
building your product and the last part concerns community one of Gatsby's core
values is do you belong here everyone belongs in open source and Gatsby is
dedicated to making contributors feel welcome to contribute we talk pretty
much every day about how to make open source more inclusive and inviting for
the community as a whole because we believe it brings out the best in all of
us so we make a conscious effort to build this philosophy into everything
that we do from an open core maintainer x' meeting where community where
community members can come share stuff that they're working on or problems that
they're running in to give the core team feedback and then they can also hear
from the core team about what's new and what's in the works to offering pair
programming sessions with community members to thanking each contributor
with some swag and an invitation to join the Gatsby
github org - an open and inclusive code of conduct and beyond so tech doesn't
exist in a vacuum it's made for humans and we believe we should strive to be
excellent to each other in the course of making software so over 1,800 people
contributed to the Gatsby mana repo and there are now almost 800 plugins so the
plug-in ecosystem is growing crazy fast thanks to contributors publishing and
maintaining plugins again we try to foster a community of giving back did
you build something really cool that other people would get some utility out
of awesome publish it share it with the community so I've talked about these
core concerns when getting started on a project you have to evaluate and
prioritize your core concerns and the time and budget that you have allotted
to determine which tool fits best with that priority set from performance
methodology to how it approaches and prioritizes accessibility to the tach it
takes in how you manage content data to the overall developer experience and how
it jives with how you'd like to work to the community around the project I
really personally think it's a really awesome time to be a dev and I really
love Gatsby we're using it to build a ton of things we're using it to run our
swag store which is a full-blown ecommerce site we're using it to run our
dot work site for everything in the Gatsby open-source ecosystem from Docs
to filterable searchable libraries for plugins and starters we're using it to
build our first commercial offering a hosted Gatsby preview service for teams
so it's an incredibly robust and flexible framework and I really have a
lot of love for it but I also have a lot of love for the vibrant ecosystem of
frameworks that have blossomed in the jams tax bases
and I urge all of you to explore all of the awesome recipes and flavors that the
